After over three years of programming in Elixir I think I finally understand the â€œLet it crashâ€ principle. I realized just how much code was being wasted gracefully handling errors that had no business being handled at all!

Basically my thinking goes like this:

If there is a meaningful error I can return to a user e.g. â€œbad auth tokenâ€, I should handle this gracefully and return the error. Otherwise, â€œlet it crashâ€!

If the database returns something I donâ€™t expect, crash! If S3 is down, crash! If a map doesnâ€™t have a key that should be there, crash!

The beautiful thing about crashing: I can see exactly what happened and where in the form of a stacktrace in the logs. If I attempt to handle something unexpected gracefully, the real issue is either shifted somewhere else OR itâ€™s swallowed completely.

This has dramatically improved my code by removing unneccesary error handling, making everything more concise and readable. I only care about the happy path!

After one year at HelloSign and many huge features later, Iâ€™m very proud that I still have a net negative 20k lines of code in the repo. I think embracing â€œlet it crashâ€ is one of the biggest factors in this!
